trans-unit.source: !optional
trans-unit.target: !optional

trans-unit.source: #always_check-option :always_check : Whether a Sass template should be checked for updates every time a controller is accessed, as opposed to only when the server starts. If a Sass template has been updated, it will be recompiled and will overwrite the corresponding CSS file. Defaults to false in production mode, true otherwise. Only has meaning within Rack, Ruby on Rails, or Merb.
trans-unit.target: # always_check-option :always_check : si se debe verificar una plantilla Sass en busca de actualizaciones cada vez que se accede a un controlador, a diferencia de solo cuando se inicia el servidor. Si se ha actualizado una plantilla de Sass, se volverá a compilar y sobrescribirá el archivo CSS correspondiente. El valor predeterminado es falso en el modo de producción, verdadero en caso contrario. Solo tiene significado en Rack, Ruby on Rails o Merb.

trans-unit.source: #always_update-option :always_update : Whether the CSS files should be updated every time a controller is accessed, as opposed to only when the template has been modified. Defaults to false. Only has meaning within Rack, Ruby on Rails, or Merb.
trans-unit.target: # always_update-option :always_update : si los archivos CSS deben actualizarse cada vez que se accede a un controlador, a diferencia de solo cuando se ha modificado la plantilla. El valor predeterminado es falso. Solo tiene significado en Rack, Ruby on Rails o Merb.

trans-unit.source: #cache-option :cache : Whether parsed Sass files should be cached, allowing greater speed. Defaults to true.
trans-unit.target: # cache-option :cache : si los archivos Sass analizados deben almacenarse en caché, lo que permite una mayor velocidad. Por defecto es verdadero.

trans-unit.source: #cache_location-option :cache_location : The path where the cached sassc files should be written to. Defaults to "./tmp/sass-cache" in Rails and Merb, or "./.sass-cache" otherwise. If the :cache_store option is set, this is ignored.
trans-unit.target: # cache_location-option :cache_location : la ruta donde se deben escribir los archivos sassc almacenados en caché . El valor predeterminado es "./tmp/sass-cache" en Rails y Merb, o "./.sass-cache" de lo contrario. Si se establece la opción :cache_store , esto se ignora.

trans-unit.source: #cache_store-option :cache_store : If this is set to an instance of a subclass of Sass::CacheStores::Base, that cache store will be used to store and retrieve cached compilation results. Defaults to a Sass::CacheStores::Filesystem that is initialized using the :cache_location option.
trans-unit.target: # cache_store-option :cache_store : Si se establece en una instancia de una subclase de Sass :: CacheStores :: Base , ese almacén de caché se utilizará para almacenar y recuperar los resultados de la compilación en caché. Por defecto es un Sass :: CacheStores :: Filesystem que se inicializa usando la opción :cache_location .

trans-unit.source: #css_location-option :css_location : The path where CSS output should be written to. This option is ignored when :template_location is a Hash. Defaults to "./public/stylesheets". Only has meaning within Rack, Ruby on Rails, or Merb.
trans-unit.target: # css_location-option :css_location : La ruta donde se debe escribir la salida CSS. Esta opción se ignora cuando :template_location es un Hash. El valor predeterminado es "./public/stylesheets" . Solo tiene significado en Rack, Ruby on Rails o Merb.

trans-unit.source: #custom-option :custom : An option that's available for individual applications to set to make data available to custom Sass functions.
trans-unit.target: # custom-option :custom : una opción que está disponible para que las aplicaciones individuales la configuren para que los datos estén disponibles para funciones personalizadas de Sass .

trans-unit.source: #debug_info-option :debug_info : When set to true, causes the line number and file where a selector is defined to be emitted into the compiled CSS in a format that can be understood by the browser. Useful in conjunction with the FireSass Firebug extension for displaying the Sass filename and line number. Automatically disabled when using the :compressed output style.
trans-unit.target: # debug_info-option :debug_info : cuando se establece en true, hace que el número de línea y el archivo donde se define un selector se emitan en el CSS compilado en un formato que el navegador pueda entender. Útil junto con la extensión FireSass Firebug para mostrar el nombre de archivo Sass y el número de línea. Se desactiva automáticamente cuando se usa el estilo de salida :compressed .

trans-unit.source: #division-and-slash
trans-unit.target: #division-and-slash

trans-unit.source: #filename-option :filename : The filename of the file being rendered. This is used solely for reporting errors, and is automatically set when using Rack, Rails, or Merb.
trans-unit.target: # filename-option :filename : el nombre de archivo del archivo que se está procesando. Se utiliza únicamente para informar errores y se configura automáticamente cuando se utiliza Rack, Rails o Merb.

trans-unit.source: #filesystem_importer-option :filesystem_importer : A Sass::Importers::Base subclass used to handle plain string load paths. This should import files from the filesystem. It should be a Class object inheriting from Sass::Importers::Base with a constructor that takes a single string argument (the load path). Defaults to Sass::Importers::Filesystem.
trans-unit.target: # filesystem_importer-option :filesystem_importer : Una subclase de Sass :: Importers :: Base utilizada para manejar rutas de carga de cadenas simples. Esto debería importar archivos del sistema de archivos. Debe ser un objeto Class heredado de Sass :: Importers :: Base con un constructor que tome un argumento de cadena única (la ruta de carga). El valor predeterminado es Sass :: Importers :: Filesystem .

trans-unit.source: #full_exception-option :full_exception : Whether an error in the Sass code should cause Sass to provide a detailed description within the generated CSS file. If set to true, the error will be displayed along with a line number and source snippet both as a comment in the CSS file and at the top of the page (in supported browsers). Otherwise, an exception will be raised in the Ruby code. Defaults to false in production mode, true otherwise.
trans-unit.target: # full_exception-option :full_exception : si un error en el código de Sass debería hacer que Sass proporcione una descripción detallada dentro del archivo CSS generado. Si se establece en verdadero, el error se mostrará junto con un número de línea y un fragmento de código fuente como comentario en el archivo CSS y en la parte superior de la página (en los navegadores compatibles). De lo contrario, se generará una excepción en el código Ruby. El valor predeterminado es falso en el modo de producción, verdadero en caso contrario.

trans-unit.source: #interpolation_
trans-unit.target: #interpolation_

trans-unit.source: #line-option :line : The number of the first line of the Sass template. Used for reporting line numbers for errors. This is useful to set if the Sass template is embedded in a Ruby file.
trans-unit.target: # line-option :line : el número de la primera línea de la plantilla Sass. Se utiliza para informar los números de línea en busca de errores. Esto es útil para establecer si la plantilla Sass está incrustada en un archivo Ruby.

trans-unit.source: #line_numbers-option :line_numbers : When set to true, causes the line number and file where a selector is defined to be emitted into the compiled CSS as a comment. Useful for debugging, especially when using imports and mixins. This option may also be called :line_comments. Automatically disabled when using the :compressed output style or the :debug_info/:trace_selectors options.
trans-unit.target: # line_numbers-option :line_numbers : cuando se establece en verdadero, hace que el número de línea y el archivo donde se define un selector se emitan en el CSS compilado como un comentario. Útil para depurar, especialmente cuando se utilizan importaciones y mixins. Esta opción también se puede llamar :line_comments . Se deshabilita automáticamente cuando se usa el estilo de salida :compressed o las :debug_info / :trace_selectors .

trans-unit.source: #load_paths-option :load_paths : An array of filesystem paths or importers which should be searched for Sass templates imported with the @import directive. These may be strings, Pathname objects, or subclasses of Sass::Importers::Base. This defaults to the working directory and, in Rack, Rails, or Merb, whatever :template_location is. The load path is also informed by Sass.load_paths and the SASS_PATH environment variable.
trans-unit.target: # load_paths-option :load_paths : Una matriz de rutas del sistema de archivos o importadores que se deben buscar para las plantillas Sass importadas con la directiva @import . Pueden ser cadenas, objetos Pathname o subclases de Sass :: Importers :: Base . Este valor predeterminado es el directorio de trabajo y, en Rack, Rails o Merb, lo que sea :template_location . La ruta de carga también es informada por Sass.load_paths y la variable de entorno SASS_PATH .

trans-unit.source: #never_update-option :never_update : Whether the CSS files should never be updated, even if the template file changes. Setting this to true may give small performance gains. It always defaults to false. Only has meaning within Rack, Ruby on Rails, or Merb.
trans-unit.target: # never_update-option :never_update : si los archivos CSS nunca deben actualizarse, incluso si cambia el archivo de plantilla. Establecer esto en verdadero puede dar pequeñas ganancias de rendimiento. Siempre tiene el valor predeterminado de falso. Solo tiene significado en Rack, Ruby on Rails o Merb.

trans-unit.source: #poll-option :poll : When true, always use the polling backend for Sass::Plugin::Compiler#watch rather than the native filesystem backend.
trans-unit.target: # poll-option :poll : cuando es verdadero, siempre use el backend de sondeo para Sass :: Plugin :: Compiler # watch en lugar del backend del sistema de archivos nativo.

trans-unit.source: #property_syntax-option :property_syntax : Forces indented-syntax documents to use one syntax for properties. If the correct syntax isn't used, an error is thrown. :new forces the use of a colon after the property name. For example: color: #0f3 or width: $main_width. :old forces the use of a colon before the property name. For example: :color #0f3 or :width $main_width. By default, either syntax is valid. This has no effect on SCSS documents.
trans-unit.target: # property_syntax-option :property_syntax : Obliga a los documentos de sintaxis con sangría a utilizar una sintaxis para las propiedades. Si no se utiliza la sintaxis correcta, se produce un error. :new fuerza el uso de dos puntos después del nombre de la propiedad. Por ejemplo: color: #0f3 o width: $main_width . :old fuerza el uso de dos puntos antes del nombre de la propiedad. Por ejemplo:: :color #0f3 o :width $main_width . De forma predeterminada, cualquier sintaxis es válida. Esto no tiene ningún efecto en los documentos SCSS.

trans-unit.source: #quiet-option :quiet : When set to true, causes warnings to be disabled.
trans-unit.target: # quiet-option :quiet : cuando se establece en verdadero, hace que las advertencias se deshabiliten.

trans-unit.source: #read_cache-option :read_cache : If this is set and :cache is not, only read the Sass cache if it exists, don't write to it if it doesn't.
trans-unit.target: # read_cache-option :read_cache : Si esto está configurado y :cache no lo está, solo lee el caché Sass si existe, no escribas en él si no lo está.

trans-unit.source: #sourcemap-option :sourcemap : Controls how sourcemaps are generated. These sourcemaps tell the browser how to find the Sass styles that caused each CSS style to be generated. This has three valid values: :auto** uses relative URIs where possible, assuming that that the source stylesheets will be made available on whatever server you're using, and that their relative location will be the same as it is on the local filesystem. If a relative URI is unavailable, a "file:" URI is used instead. **:file** always uses "file:" URIs, which will work locally but can't be deployed to a remote server. **:inline** includes the full source text in the sourcemap, which is maximally portable but can create very large sourcemap files. Finally, **:none causes no sourcemaps to be generated at all.
trans-unit.target: # sourcemap-option :sourcemap : Controla cómo se generan los mapas de origen. Estos mapas de origen le dicen al navegador cómo encontrar los estilos Sass que hicieron que se generara cada estilo CSS. Esto tiene tres valores válidos :auto ** usa URI relativos siempre que sea posible, asumiendo que las hojas de estilo de origen estarán disponibles en cualquier servidor que esté usando, y que su ubicación relativa será la misma que en el sistema de archivos local . Si un URI relativo no está disponible, en su lugar se utiliza un URI "file:". ** :file ** siempre usa "file:" URI, que funcionarán localmente pero no se pueden implementar en un servidor remoto. ** :inline ** incluye el texto fuente completo en el mapa fuente, que es máximamente portátil pero puede crear archivos de mapas fuente muy grandes. Finalmente,** :none hace que no se generen mapas de origen.

trans-unit.source: #style-option :style : Sets the style of the CSS output. See Output Style.
trans-unit.target: # style-option :style : establece el estilo de la salida CSS. Consulte Estilo de salida .

trans-unit.source: #subtraction
trans-unit.target: #subtraction

trans-unit.source: #syntax-option :syntax : The syntax of the input file, :sass for the indented syntax and :scss for the CSS-extension syntax. This is only useful when you're constructing Sass::Engine instances yourself; it's automatically set properly when using Sass::Plugin. Defaults to :sass.
trans-unit.target: # syntax-option :syntax : La sintaxis del archivo de entrada :scss :sass para la sintaxis con sangría y : scss para la sintaxis de extensión CSS. Esto solo es útil cuando está construyendo instancias de Sass :: Engine usted mismo; se configura automáticamente correctamente cuando se usa Sass :: Plugin . El valor predeterminado es :sass .

trans-unit.source: #template_location-option :template_location : A path to the root sass template directory for your application. If a hash, :css_location is ignored and this option designates a mapping between input and output directories. May also be given a list of 2-element lists, instead of a hash. Defaults to css_location + "/sass". Only has meaning within Rack, Ruby on Rails, or Merb. Note that if multiple template locations are specified, all of them are placed in the import path, allowing you to import between them. Note that due to the many possible formats it can take, this option should only be set directly, not accessed or modified. Use the Sass::Plugin#template_location_array, Sass::Plugin#add_template_location, and Sass::Plugin#remove_template_location methods instead.
trans-unit.target: # template_location-option :template_location : una ruta al directorio raíz de la plantilla sass para su aplicación. Si un hash :css_location se ignora y esta opción designa una asignación entre los directorios de entrada y salida. También se le puede dar una lista de listas de 2 elementos, en lugar de un hash. El valor predeterminado es css_location + "/sass" . Solo tiene significado en Rack, Ruby on Rails o Merb. Tenga en cuenta que si se especifican varias ubicaciones de plantilla, todas se colocan en la ruta de importación, lo que le permite importar entre ellas. Tenga en cuenta que debido a los muchos formatos posibles que puede tomar, esta opción solo debe configurarse directamente, no debe accederse a ella ni modificarse. Utilice Sass :: Plugin # template_location_array , Sass :: Plugin # add_template_locationy los métodos Sass :: Plugin # remove_template_location en su lugar .

trans-unit.source: #trace_selectors-option :trace_selectors : When set to true, emit a full trace of imports and mixins before each selector. This can be helpful for in-browser debugging of stylesheet imports and mixin includes. This option supersedes the :line_comments option and is superseded by the :debug_info option. Automatically disabled when using the :compressed output style.
trans-unit.target: # trace_selectors-option :trace_selectors : cuando se establece en true, emite un rastro completo de importaciones y mixins antes de cada selector. Esto puede resultar útil para la depuración en el navegador de las importaciones de hojas de estilo y las inclusiones mixtas. Esta opción reemplaza a la opción :line_comments y es reemplazada por la opción :debug_info . Se desactiva automáticamente cuando se usa el estilo de salida :compressed .

trans-unit.source: #unix_newlines-option :unix_newlines : If true, use Unix-style newlines when writing files. Only has meaning on Windows, and only when Sass is writing the files (in Rack, Rails, or Merb, when using Sass::Plugin directly, or when using the command-line executable).
trans-unit.target: # unix_newlines-option :unix_newlines : Si es verdadero, use nuevas líneas al estilo Unix al escribir archivos. Solo tiene significado en Windows, y solo cuando Sass está escribiendo los archivos (en Rack, Rails o Merb, cuando se usa Sass :: Plugin directamente o cuando se usa el ejecutable de la línea de comandos).

trans-unit.source: color.adjust() for adjusting a color’s properties by fixed amounts.
color.adjust() for changing a color’s properties by fixed amounts.
color.alpha() for getting a color’s alpha channel.
color.blackness() for getting a color’s blackness.
color.blue() for getting a color’s blue channel.
color.change() for setting a color’s properties.

A few functions are only available globally even in the new module system, either because they have special evaluation behavior (if()) or because they add extra behavior on top of built-in CSS functions (rgb() and hsl()). These will not be deprecated and can be used freely.
color.green() for getting a color’s green channel.
color.hue() for getting a color’s hue.
color.lightness() for getting a color’s lightness.
color.red() for getting a color’s red channel.
color.saturation() for getting a color’s saturation.
color.scale() for fluidly scaling a color’s properties.
color.whiteness() for getting a color’s whiteness.
Flow control at-rules, like @if and @each.
CSS at-rules, like @media and @font-face.
Function calls, like nth($list, 1) or var(--main-bg-color), which may call Sass core library functions or user-defined functions, or which may be compiled directly to CSS.
Function definitions using @function.

Functions can be values too! You can’t directly write a function as a value, but you can pass a function’s name to the [meta.get-function() function][] to get it as a value. Once you have a function value, you can pass it to the meta.call() function to call it. This is useful for writing higher-order functions that call other functions.
Imports, using @import.
Mixin definitions using @mixin.
Mixin uses using @include.
Module loads, using @use.
( and ) can be used to explicitly control the precedence order of operations.
and, or, and not have the usual boolean behavior. Sass considers every value “true” except for false and null.
== and != are used to check if two values are the same.
+, -, *, /, and % have their usual mathematical meaning for numbers, with special behaviors for units that matches the use of units in scientific math.
<, <=, >, and >= check whether two numbers are greater or less than one another.
+, -, and / can be used to concatenate strings.
Style rules, like h1 { /* ... */ }.
Property declarations like width: 100px may only be used within style rules and some CSS at-rules.
The parent selector, &.
true, false, and null are only equal to themselves.
Colors are equal if they have the same red, green, blue, and alpha values.
Colors, which can be referred to by their hex representation or by name, like #c6538c or blue.

Functions are equal to the same function. Functions are compared by reference, so even if two functions have the same name and definition they’re considered different if they aren’t defined in the same place.
Lists of values, which may be separated by spaces or commas and which may be enclosed in square brackets or no brackets at all, like 1.5em 1em 0 2em, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif, or [col1-start].
Lists are equal if their contents are equal. Comma-separated lists aren’t equal to space-separated lists, and bracketed lists aren’t equal to unbracketed lists.
Maps are equal if their keys and values are both equal.
Maps that associate values with keys, like ("background": red, "foreground": pink).
Numbers are equal if they have the same value and the same units, or if their values are equal when their units are converted between one another.
Numbers, which may or may not have units, like 12 or 100px.
Strings are unusual in that unquoted and quoted strings with the same contents are considered equal.
Strings, which may or may not have quotes, like "Helvetica Neue" or bold.
Variable declarations, like $var: value.
Variables, like $var.
@at-root puts styles within it at the root of the CSS document.
@debug prints a message for debugging purposes.
@error causes compilation to fail with an error message.
@extend allows selectors to inherit styles from one another.
@forward loads a Sass stylesheet and makes its mixins, functions, and variables available when your stylesheet is loaded with the @use rule.
@function defines custom functions that can be used in SassScript expressions.
@import extends the CSS at-rule to load styles, mixins, functions, and variables from other stylesheets.
@mixin and @include makes it easy to re-use chunks of styles.
@use loads mixins, functions, and variables from other Sass stylesheets, and combines CSS from multiple stylesheets together.
@warn prints a warning without stopping compilation entirely.
Dart Sass has the same command-line interface no matter how you install it.
Ruby Sass is deprecated, and we recommend you move to a different implementation.
@each evaluates a block for each element in a list or each pair in a map.
@for evaluates a block a certain number of times.
@if controls whether or not a block is evaluated.
@while evaluates a block until a certain condition is met.
@extend rules are also global, which makes it difficult to predict which style rules will be extended.

expression() and functions beginning with progid: are legacy Internet Explorer features that use non-standard syntax. Although they’re no longer supported by recent browsers, Sass continues to parse them for backwards compatibility.

CSS custom properties, also known as CSS variables, have an unusual declaration syntax: they allow almost any text at all in their declaration values. What’s more, those values are accessible to JavaScript, so any value might potentially be relevant to the user. This includes values that would normally be parsed as SassScript.
CSS color names are parsed as colors.
Node Sass and Dart Sass on npm provide an importer option as part of their JSAPI.
Dart Sass on pub provides an abstract Importer class that can be extended by a custom importer.
Ruby Sass has reached end of life and is now totally unmaintained. Please switch to Dart Sass or LibSass at your earliest convenience.
Ruby Sass provides an abstract Importers::Base class that can be extended by a custom importer.
and, or, and not have the usual boolean behavior. Sass considers every value “true” except for false and null.
== and != are used to check if two values are the same.
+, -, *, /, and % have their usual mathematical meaning for numbers, with special behaviors for units that matches the use of units in scientific math.
<, <=, >, and >= check whether two numbers are greater or less than one another.
+, -, and / can be used to concatenate strings.
Special functions, like calc(1px + 100%) or url(http://myapp.com/assets/logo.png), that have their own unique parsing rules.
Colors, which can be referred to by their hex representation or by name, like #c6538c or blue, or returned from functions, like rgb(107, 113, 127) or hsl(210, 100%, 20%).
Function references returned by get-function() and called with call().
Lists of values, which may be separated by spaces or commas and which may be enclosed in square brackets or no brackets at all, like 1.5em 1em 0 2em, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif, or [col1-start].
Maps that associate values with keys, like ("background": red, "foreground": pink).
Numbers, which may or may not have units, like 12 or 100px.

trans-unit.source: <expression> % <expression> returns the remainder of the first expression’s value divided by the second’s. This is known as the modulo operator.
<expression> > <expression> returns whether the first expression’s value is greater than to the second’s.
<expression> >= <expression>, returns whether the first expression’s value is greater than or equal to the second’s.
<expression> < <expression> returns whether the first expression’s value is less than the second’s.
<expression> <= <expression> returns whether the first expression’s value is less than or equal to the second’s.
<expression> * <expression> multiplies the first expression’s value by the second’s.
<expression> + <expression> adds the first expression’s value to the second’s.
<expression> + <expression> returns a string that contains both expressions’ values. If the either value is a quoted string, the result will be quoted; otherwise, it will be unquoted.
<expression> - <expression> returns an unquoted string that contains both expressions’ values, separated by -. This is a legacy operator, and interpolation should generally be used instead.
<expression> - <expression> subtracts the first expression’s value from the second’s.
<expression> / <expression> divides the first expression’s value by the second’s.
<expression> / <expression> returns an unquoted string that contains both expressions’ values, separated by /.
<expression> and <expression> returns true if both expressions’ values are true, and false if either is false.
<expression> or <expression> returns true if either expression’s value is true, and false if both are false.

-<expression> returns the negative version of the expression’s value.

- between two numbers regardless of whitespace, which is parsed as subtraction.
/<expression> returns an unquoted string starting with / and followed by the expression’s value.

trans-unit.source: @media directives in Sass behave just like they do in plain CSS, with one extra capability: they can be nested in CSS rules. trans-unit.source: A Sass stylesheet is made up of a series of statements, which are evaluated in order to build the resulting CSS. Some statements may have blocks, defined using { and }, which contain other statements. For example, a style rule is a statement with a block. That block contains other statements, such as property declarations.
A Sass stylesheet is parsed from a sequence of Unicode code points. It's parsed directly, without first being converted to a token stream.

A common issue users encounter with named colors is that since Sass prefers the same output format as was typed in other output modes, a color interpolated into a selector becomes invalid syntax when compressed. To avoid this, always quote named colors if they are meant to be used in the construction of a selector.

trans-unit.source: All value types support methods that modify the value objects. Users are strongly discouraged from using these methods (except for the Map type and List type where they’re necessary to create new values), because they don’t match the general principle that Sass values are immutable. Users should construct new objects rather than modifying existing ones.
All versions of Node Sass and Dart Sass otherwise support the file option as described below.

All versions of Node Sass currently pass imports to importers before loading them relative to the file in which the @import appears. This behavior is considered incorrect and should not be relied on because it violates the principle of locality, which says that it should be possible to reason about a stylesheet without knowing everything about how the entire system is set up. If a user tries to import a stylesheet relative to another stylesheet, that import should always work. It shouldn’t be possible for some configuration somewhere else to break it.

Although @while is necessary for a few particularly complex stylesheets, you’re usually better of using either @each or @for if either of them will work. They’re clearer for the reader, and often faster to compile as well.

Although Sass imports can’t use interpolation (to make sure it’s always possible to tell where mixins, functions, and variables come from), plain CSS imports can. This makes it possible to dynamically generate imports, for example based on mixin parameters.

Although most of the time it's most useful to just have @imports at the top level of the document, it is possible to include them within CSS rules and @media rules. Like a base-level @import, this includes the contents of the @imported file. However, the imported rules will be nested in the same place as the original @import.

Como un @import de nivel básico , esto incluye el contenido del archivo @import ed. Sin embargo, las reglas importadas se anidarán en el mismo lugar que el @import original .

An Error object, indicating that importing failed.
An @if rule can optionally be followed by an @else rule, written @else { ... }. This rule’s block is evaluated if the @if expression returns false.

An expression is anything that goes on the right-hand side of a property or variable declaration. Each expression produces a value. Any valid CSS property value is also a Sass expression, but Sass expressions are much more powerful than plain CSS values. They’re passed as arguments to mixins and functions, used for control flow with the @if rule, and manipulated using arithmetic. We call Sass’s expression syntax SassScript.

An API that makes sense for @use might not make sense for @import. For example, @use adds a namespace to all members by default so you can safely use short names, but @import doesn’t so you might need something longer. If you’re a library author, you may be concerned that if you update your library to use the new module system, your existing @import-based users will break.

An array of the absolute paths of all Sass files loaded during compilation. If a stylesheet was loaded from an importer that returned the stylesheet’s contents, the raw string of the @use or @import that loaded that stylesheet is included in this array.
An object with the key contents whose value is the contents of a stylesheet (in SCSS syntax). This causes Sass to load that stylesheet’s contents.

trans-unit.source: As a convention, Sass files that are only meant to be imported, not compiled on their own, begin with _ (as in _code.scss). These are called partials, and they tell Sass tools not to try to compile those files on their own. You can leave off the _ when importing a partial.

As a convention, Sass files that are only meant to be loaded as modules, not compiled on their own, begin with _ (as in _code.scss). These are called partials, and they tell Sass tools not to try to compile those files on their own. You can leave off the _ when importing a partial.

Because @use adds namespaces to member names, it’s safe to choose very simple names like $radius or $width when writing a stylesheet. This is different from the old @import rule, which encouraged that users write long names like $mat-corner-radius to avoid conflicts with other libraries, and it helps keep your stylesheets clear and easy to read!
Because adjust-hue() is redundant with adjust(), it’s not included directly in the new module system. Instead of adjust-hue($color, $amount), you can write color.adjust($color, $hue: $amount).

Because darken() is usually not the best way to make a color darker, it’s not included directly in the new module system. However, if you have to preserve the existing behavior, darken($color, $amount) can be written color.adjust($color, $lightness: -$amount).

Because desaturate() is usually not the best way to make a color less saturated, it’s not included directly in the new module system. However, if you have to preserve the existing behavior, desaturate($color, $amount) can be written color.adjust($color, $saturation: -$amount).

Because lighten() is usually not the best way to make a color lighter, it’s not included directly in the new module system. However, if you have to preserve the existing behavior, lighten($color, $amount) can be written adjust($color, $lightness: $amount).

Because opacify() is usually not the best way to make a color more opaque, it’s not included directly in the new module system. However, if you have to preserve the existing behavior, opacify($color, $amount) can be written adjust($color, $alpha: -$amount).

Because saturate() is usually not the best way to make a color more saturated, it’s not included directly in the new module system. However, if you have to preserve the existing behavior, saturate($color, $amount) can be written adjust($color, $saturation: $amount).

Because transparentize() is usually not the best way to make a color more transparent, it’s not included directly in the new module system. However, if you have to preserve the existing behavior, transparentize($color, $amount) can be written color.adjust($color, $alpha: -$amount).

Because any argument can be passed by name, be careful when renaming a function’s arguments… it might break your users! It can be helpful to keep the old name around as an optional argument for a while and printing a warning if anyone passes it, so they know to migrate to the new argument.

Because any argument can be passed by name, be careful when renaming a mixin’s arguments… it might break your users! It can be helpful to keep the old name around as an optional argument for a while and printing a warning if anyone passes it, so they know to migrate to the new argument.

Because CSS doesn’t support complex units like square pixels, using a number with complex units as a property value will produce an error. And remember, you can always use the @debug rule to check out the units of any variable or expression.

Because everything’s global, libraries must prefix to all their members to avoid naming collisions.

CSS added support for min() and max() functions in Values and Units Level 4, from where they were quickly adopted by Safari to support the iPhoneX. But Sass supported its own min() and max() functions long before this, and it needed to be backwards-compatible with all those existing stylesheets. This led for the need for extra-special syntactic cleverness.

CSS allows / to appear in property values as a way of separating numbers. Since SassScript is an extension of the CSS property syntax, it must support this, while also allowing / to be used for division. This means that by default, if two numbers are separated by / in SassScript, then they will appear that way in the resulting CSS.

Esto significa que, de forma predeterminada, si dos números están separados por / en SassScript, aparecerán de esa manera en el CSS resultante.

trans-unit.source: CSS at-rules

CSS defines many functions, and most of them work just fine with Sass’s normal function syntax. They’re parsed as function calls, resolved to plain CSS functions, and compiled as-is to CSS. There are a few exceptions, though, which have special syntax that can’t just be parsed as a SassScript expression. All special function calls return unquoted strings.

CSS files imported by Sass don’t allow any special Sass features. In order to make sure authors don’t accidentally write Sass in their CSS, all Sass features that aren’t also valid CSS will produce errors. Otherwise, the CSS will be rendered as-is. It can even be extended!

CSS files loaded as modules don’t allow any special Sass features and so can’t expose any Sass variables, functions, or mixins. In order to make sure authors don’t accidentally write Sass in their CSS, all Sass features that aren’t also valid CSS will produce errors. Otherwise, the CSS will be rendered as-is. It can even be extended!
CSS has variables of its own, which are totally different than Sass variables. Know the differences!

trans-unit.source: Comments can also be used within expressions in the indented syntax. In this case, they have exactly the same syntax as they do in SCSS.

Comments in SCSS work similarly to comments in other languages like JavaScript. Single-line comments start with //, and go until the end of the line. Nothing in a single-line comment is emitted as CSS; as far as Sass is concerned, they may as well not exist. They’re also called silent comments, because they don’t produce any CSS.

Comments in the indented syntax work a little differently: they’re indentation-based, just like the rest of the syntax. Like SCSS, silent comments written with // are never emitted as CSS, but unlike SCSS everything indented beneath the opening // is also commented out.

trans-unit.source: Configuring Modules
Configuring Modules Through Imports

Configuring modules with @use ... with can be very handy, especially when using libraries that were originally written to work with the @import rule. But it’s not particularly flexible, and we don’t recommend it for more advanced use-cases. If you find yourself wanting to configure many variables at once, pass maps as configuration, or update the configuration after the module is loaded, consider writing a mixin to set your variables instead and another mixin to inject your styles.

trans-unit.source: Extends $selector as with the @extend rule.

Extends and mixins are both ways of encapsulating and re-using styles in Sass, which naturally raises the question of when to use which one. Mixins are obviously necessary when you need to configure the styles using arguments, but what if they’re just a chunk of styles?

Extends are resolved after the rest of your stylesheet is compiled. In particular, it happens after parent selectors are resolved. This means that if you @extend .error, it won’t affect the inner selector in .error { &__icon { ... } }. It also means that parent selectors in SassScript can’t see the results of extend.
Extends or Mixins?
Extension Scope

Extensions aren’t scoped at all if you’re using the @import rule. Not only will they affect every stylesheet you import, they’ll affect every stylesheet that imports your stylesheet, everything else those stylesheets import, and so on. Without @use, extensions are global.

Fluidly scales one or more properties of $color.

Fluidly scales one or more properties of a color. Unlike adjust-color, which changes a color's properties by fixed amounts, scale-color fluidly changes them based on how high or low they already are. That means that lightening an already-light color with scale-color won't change the lightness much, but lightening a dark color by the same amount will change it more dramatically. This has the benefit of making scale-color($color, ...) have a similar effect regardless of what $color is.
trans-unit.target: Escala de forma fluida una o más propiedades de un color. A diferencia del color de ajuste , que cambia las propiedades de un color en cantidades fijas, el color de escala las cambia de manera fluida en función de lo alto o bajo que ya sea. Eso significa que aclarar un color que ya es claro con un color de escala no cambiará mucho la claridad, pero aclarar un color oscuro en la misma cantidad lo cambiará de manera más dramática. Esto tiene la ventaja de hacer que scale-color($color, ...) tenga un efecto similar independientemente de qué $color sea.

trans-unit.source: Function names, like all Sass identifiers, treat hyphens and underscores as identical. This means that scale-color and scale_color both refer to the same function. This is a historical holdover from the very early days of Sass, when it only allowed underscores in identifier names. Once Sass added support for hyphens to match CSS’s syntax, the two were made equivalent to make migration easier.
Functions
trans-unit.target: Functions

trans-unit.source: Functions allow you to define complex operations on SassScript values that you can re-use throughout your stylesheet. They make it easy to abstract out common formulas and behaviors in a readable way.

Functions are defined using the @function at-rule, which is written @function <name>(<arguments...>) { ... }. A function’s name can be any Sass identifier. It can only contain universal statements, as well as the @return at-rule which indicates the value to use as the result of the function call. Functions are called using the normal CSS function syntax.

Functions are passed JavaScript representations of Sass value types, and must return the same. All functions can return synchronously, but functions passed to the asynchronous render() function can also take an additional callback to which they can asynchronously pass the result of the function when it’s complete.

If $module is null, this returns the function named $name without a namespace (including global built-in functions). Otherwise, $module must be a string matching the namespace of a @use rule in the current file, in which case this returns the function in that module named $name.

If $module is null, this returns whether a mixin named $name without a namespace exists. Otherwise, $module must be a string matching the namespace of a @use rule in the current file, in which case this returns whether that module has a mixin named $name.

If $module is null, this returns whether a variable named $name without a namespace exists. Otherwise, $module must be a string matching the namespace of a @use rule in the current file, in which case this returns whether that module has a variable named $name.
If $n is negative, it counts from the end of $list. Throws an error if there is no element at index $n.

If $separator is comma, the returned list is comma-separated. If it’s space, the returned list is space-separated. If it’s auto (the default), the returned list will use the same separator as $list (or space if $list doesn’t have a separator). Other values aren’t allowed.

If $separator is comma, the returned list is comma-separted. If it’s space, the returned list is space-separated. If it’s auto (the default), the returned list will use the same separator as $list1 if it has a separator, or else $list2 if it has a separator, or else space. Other values aren’t allowed.
If $url is relative, it’s interpreted as relative to the file in which meta.load-css() is included.
If $value doesn’t appear in $list, this returns null. If $value appears multiple times in $list, this returns the index of its first appearance.
If a list contains a null, that null is omitted from the generated CSS.

If a min() or max() function call is valid plain CSS, it will be compiled to a CSSmin() or max() call. “Plain CSS” includes nested calls to calc(), env(), var(), min(), or max(), as well as interpolation. As soon as any part of the call contains a SassScript feature like variables or function calls, though, it’s parsed as a call to Sass’s core min() or max() function instead.

If a CSS at-rule is nested within a style rule, the two automatically swap positions so that the at-rule is at the top level of the CSS output and the style rule is within it. This makes it easy to add conditional styling without having to rewrite the style rule’s selector.
If a function synchronously throws an error, that error is reported to the caller of the function and stylesheet compilation fails. There’s currently no way to asynchronously report an error.
If a key in $keys doesn’t have an associated value in $map, it’s ignored.

If a mixin passes arguments to its content block, that content block must declare that it accepts those arguments. This means that it’s a good idea to only pass arguments by position (rather than by name), and it means that passing more arguments is a breaking change.
If a number is less than 0.0000000001 away from an integer, it’s considered to be an integer for the purposes of functions like list.nth() that require integer arguments.
If a property value is null, that property is omitted entirely.

If an input file is passed without a corresponding output file, it’s compiled to a CSS file named after the input file, but with the extension replaced with .css. If an input directory is passed without a corresponding output directory, all the Sass files within it are compiled to CSS files in the same directory.
If any selector in $selectors is a selector list, each complex selector is combined separately.
If both $map1 and $map2 have the same key, $map2’s value takes precedence.
If both maps have the same keys, the second map’s values are used in the map that gets returned.
If it’s a printable character other than a newline or a tab, it’s included after a \. For example, \21 returns the unquoted string \!.
If it’s a valid identifier character, it’s included unescaped in the unquoted string. For example, \1F46D returns the unquoted string .
If no $keys are passed, returns a new map with all the keys and values from both $map1 and $map2.

If none of the above conditions are met and the extension is .scss or .sass, then the named Sass or SCSS file will be imported. If there is no extension, Sass will try to find a file with that name and the .scss or .sass extension and import it.

Each variable name is assigned to the value at the corresponding position in the list, or null if the list doesn’t have enough values.

If you need to check if an element is in a list or figure out what index it’s at, use the list.index($list, $value) function. This takes a list and a value to locate in that list, and returns the index of that value.

If you need to set a global variable’s value from within a local scope (such as in a mixin), you can use the !global flag. A variable declaration flagged as !global will always assign to the global scope.

Imports are resolved by trying, in order:

Imports are usually written at the top level of a stylesheet, but they don’t have to be. They can nested within style rules or plain CSS at-rules as well. The imported CSS is nested in that context, which makes nested imports useful for scoping a chunk of CSS to a particular element or media query. Note that top-level mixins, functions, and variables defined in the nested import are still defined globally, though.

Imports may contain #{} interpolation, but only with certain restrictions. It's not possible to dynamically import a Sass file based on a variable; interpolation is only for CSS imports. As such, it only works with url() imports. For example:

No es posible importar dinámicamente un archivo Sass basado en una variable; la interpolación es solo para importaciones CSS. Como tal, solo funciona con importaciones de url() . Por ejemplo:

Imports will always be resolved relative to the current file first, though. Load paths will only be used if no relative file exists that matches the import. This ensures that you can’t accidentally mess up your relative imports when you add a new library.
In SCSS
In SCSS, statements are separated by semicolons (which are optional if the statement uses a block). In the indented syntax, they’re just separated by newlines.
In Sass

In Sass as in CSS, property declarations define how elements that match a selector are styled. But Sass adds extra features to make them easier to write and to automate. First and foremost, a declaration's value can be any SassScript expression, which will be evaluated and included in the result.
In Sass, every map counts as a list that contains a two-element list for each key/value pair. For example, (1: 2, 3: 4) counts as (1 2, 3 4). So all these functions work for maps as well!
In SassScript

In addition to containing simple values, lists can contain other lists. For example, 1px 2px, 5px 6px is a two-item list containing the list 1px 2px and the list 5px 6px. If the inner lists have the same separator as the outer list, you'll need to use parentheses to make it clear where the inner lists start and stop. For example, (1px 2px) (5px 6px) is also a two-item list containing the list 1px 2px and the list 5px 6px. The difference is that the outer list is space-separated, where before it was comma-separated.
trans-unit.target: Además de contener valores simples, las listas pueden contener otras listas. Por ejemplo, 1px 2px, 5px 6px es una lista de dos elementos que contiene la lista 1px 2px y la lista 5px 6px . Si las listas internas tienen el mismo separador que la lista externa, deberá usar paréntesis para dejar en claro dónde comienzan y terminan las listas internas. Por ejemplo, (1px 2px) (5px 6px) también es una lista de dos elementos que contiene la lista 1px 2px y la lista 5px 6px . La diferencia es que la lista exterior está separada por espacios, donde antes estaba separada por comas.

In addition to taking arguments, a mixin can take an entire block of styles, known as a content block. A mixin can declare that it takes a content block by including the @content at-rule in its body. The content block is passed in using curly braces like any other block in Sass, and it’s injected in place of the @content rule.

It wouldn’t be any fun to write out absolute URLs for every stylesheet you import, so Sass’s algorithm for finding a file to import makes it a little easier. It wouldn’t be any fun to write out absolute URLs for every stylesheet you load, so Sass’s algorithm for finding a module makes it a little easier. It’s almost always a bad idea to use interpolation with numbers. Interpolation returns unquoted strings that can’t be used for any further math, and it avoids Sass’s built-in safeguards to ensure that units are used correctly.

It’s also useful to add elements to a list. The list.append($list, $val) function takes a list and a value, and returns a copy of the list with the value added to the end. Note that because Sass lists are immutable, it doesn’t modify the original list.

It’s also useful to add new pairs to a map, or to replace the value for an existing key. The map.set($map, $key, $value) function does this: it returns a copy of $map with the value at $key set to $value.

It’s often cleaner and clearer to use interpolation to create strings, rather than relying on this operators.

trans-unit.source: LibSass and Ruby Sass currently always parse min() and max() as Sass functions. To create a plain CSSmin() or max() call for those implementations, you can write something like unquote("min(#{$padding}, env(safe-area-inset-left))") instead.

LibSass and Ruby Sass currently allow compound selectors like .message.info to be extended. However, this behavior doesn’t match the definition of @extend: instead of styling elements that match the extending selector as though it had class="message info", which would be affected by style rules that included either .messageor.info, it only styled them with rules that included both .messageandinfo.

LibSass and Ruby Sass currently use an older syntax for parsing interpolation in SassScript. For most practical purposes it works the same, but it can behave strangely around operators. See this document for details.
LibSass and Ruby Sass only support the following signatures:
LibSass and older versions of Dart Sass and Ruby Sass don’t support media queries with features written in a range context. They do support other standard media queries.
LibSass and older versions of Dart or Ruby Sass don’t support hex colors with an alpha channel.

LibSass and older versions of Ruby Sass consider numbers without units to be equal to the same numbers with any units. This behavior was deprecated and has been removed from more recently releases because it violates transitivity.

LibSass and older versions of Ruby Sass default to 5 digits of numeric precision, but can be configured to use a different number. It’s recommended that users configure them for 10 digits for greater accuracy and forwards-compatibility.
LibSass and older versions of Ruby Sass don’t support alpha values specified as percentages.

LibSass supports importing files with the extension .css, but contrary to the specification they’re treated as SCSS files rather than being parsed as CSS. This behavior has been deprecated, and an update is in the works to support the behavior described below.

LibSass, Ruby Sass, and older versions of Dart Sass don’t normalize escapes in identifiers. Instead, the text in the unquoted string is the exact text the user wrote. For example, \1F46D and are not considered equivalent.
LibSass, Ruby Sass, and older versions of Dart Sass don’t support interpolation in at-rule names. They do support interpolation in values.

trans-unit.source: Like lists, maps are mostly manipulated using SassScript functions. The map-get function looks up values in a map and the map-merge function adds values to a map. trans-unit.source: Like selectors generated by the @extend rule, the returned selector isn’t guaranteed to match all the elements matched by both $selector1 and $selector2 if they’re both complex selectors.

Like the selector unification done for @extend, this doesn't guarantee that the output selector will match all elements matched by both input selectors. For example, if .a .b is unified with .x .y, .a .x .b.y, .x .a .b.y will be returned, but .a.x .b.y will not. This avoids exponential output size while matching all elements that are likely to exist in practice.
trans-unit.target: Al igual que la unificación del selector realizada para @extend , esto no garantiza que el selector de salida coincidirá con todos los elementos coincidentes con ambos selectores de entrada. Por ejemplo, si .a .b está unificado con .x .y , .a .x .b.y, .x .a .b.y se devolverá, pero .a.x .b.y no. Esto evita un tamaño de salida exponencial al tiempo que hace coincidir todos los elementos que probablemente existan en la práctica.

trans-unit.source: Lists
trans-unit.target: Lists

trans-unit.source: Lists are how Sass represents the values of CSS declarations like margin: 10px 15px 0 0 or font-face: Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif. Lists are just a series of other values, separated by either spaces or commas. In fact, individual values count as lists, too: they're just lists with one item.
trans-unit.target: Las listas son cómo Sass representa los valores de las declaraciones CSS como margin: 10px 15px 0 0 o font-face: Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif . Las listas son solo una serie de otros valores, separados por espacios o comas. De hecho, los valores individuales también cuentan como listas: son solo listas con un elemento.

trans-unit.source: Lists aren’t much use if you can’t get values out of them. You can use the list.nth($list, $n) function to get the element at a given index in a list. The first argument is the list itself, and the second is the index of the value you want to get out.

Lists can also be written with square brackets—we call these bracketed lists. Bracketed lists containing are used as line names in CSS Grid Layout, but they can also be used in pure Sass code just like any other list. Bracketed lists can be comma- or space-separated.
trans-unit.target: Las listas también se pueden escribir con corchetes; las llamamos listas entre corchetes. Las listas entre corchetes que contienen se usan como nombres de línea en CSS Grid Layout , pero también se pueden usar en código Sass puro como cualquier otra lista. Las listas entre corchetes pueden estar separadas por comas o espacios.

trans-unit.source: Lists can also have no items in them at all. These lists are represented as () (which is also an empty map). They can't be output directly to CSS; if you try to do e.g. font-family: (), Sass will raise an error. If a list contains empty lists or null values, as in 1px 2px () 3px or 1px 2px null 3px, the empty lists and null values will be removed before the containing list is turned into CSS.
trans-unit.target: Las listas tampoco pueden tener elementos en absoluto. Estas listas se representan como () (que también es un mapa vacío ). No se pueden enviar directamente a CSS; si intenta hacer, por ejemplo, font-family: () , Sass generará un error. Si una lista contiene listas vacías o valores nulos, como en 1px 2px () 3px o 1px 2px null 3px , las listas vacías y los valores nulos se eliminarán antes de que la lista contenedora se convierta en CSS.

trans-unit.source: Lists contain a sequence of other values. In Sass, elements in lists can be separated by commas (Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif) or by spaces (10px 15px 0 0), as long as it’s consistent within the list. Unlike most other languages, lists in Sass don’t require special brackets; any expressions separated with spaces or commas count as a list. However, you’re allowed to write lists with square brackets ([line1 line2]), which is useful when using grid-template-columns.
Lists don't support any special operations. Instead, they're manipulated using the list functions.
trans-unit.target: Las listas no admiten operaciones especiales. En cambio, se manipulan mediante las funciones de lista .

trans-unit.source: Lists in Sass are immutable, which means that the contents of a list value never changes. Sass’s list functions all return new lists rather than modifying the originals. Immutability helps avoid lots of sneaky bugs that can creep in when the same list is shared across different parts of the stylesheet.

trans-unit.source: Load Paths

Load paths are also loaded from the SASS_PATHenvironment variable, if it’s set. This variable should be a list of paths separated by ; (on Windows) or : (on other operating systems). Load paths from the includePaths option take precedence over load paths from SASS_PATH.

Load paths are also loaded from the SASS_PATHenvironment variable, if it’s set. This variable should be a list of paths separated by ; (on Windows) or : (on other operating systems). Load paths on SASS_PATH take precedence over load paths passed on the command line.

Loading a Module That Contains Imports
Loading a file relative to the current working directory.
Loading a file relative to the file in which the @use or @import appeared.

Loads the module at $url and includes its CSS as though it were written as the contents of this mixin. The $with parameter provides configuration for the modules; if it’s passed, it must be a map from variable names (without $) to the values of those variables to use in the loaded module.

Local variables can even be declared with the same name as a global variable. If this happens, there are actually two different variables with the same name: one local and one global. This helps ensure that an author writing a local variable doesn’t accidentally change the value of a global variable they aren’t even aware of.
